message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Nonreciprocal Ising Model
Paper Abstract: Systems with nonreciprocal interactions generically display time-dependent states. These are routinely observed in finite systems, from neuroscience to active matter, in which globally ordered oscillations exist. However, the stability of these uniform nonreciprocal phases in noisy spatially-extended systems, their fate in the thermodynamic limit, and the critical behavior of the corresponding phase transitions are not fully understood. Here, we address these questions by introducing a nonreciprocal generalization of the Ising model and study its phase transitions by means of numerical and analytical approaches. While the mean-field equations predict three stable homogeneous phases (disordered, ordered, and a time-dependent swap phase), our large scale numerical simulations reveal a more complex picture. Static order is destroyed in any finite dimension due to the growth of rare droplets unless the symmetry between the two spin types is broken, triggering a stabilizing droplet-capture mechanism. The swap phase is destroyed by fluctuations in two dimensions through the proliferation of spiral defects but stabilized in three dimensions, where nonreciprocity changes the critical exponents from Ising to XY, thus giving rise to a robust spatially-distributed clock.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Critical exponent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_exponent"},{"title":"Ising critical exponents","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Critical exponent of a word - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_exponent_of_a_word"},{"title":"Percolation critical exponents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percolation_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Critical phenomena - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_phenomena"},{"title":"Category:Critical exponents (phase transitions) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Critical_exponents_(phase_transitions)"},{"title":"Critical dimension - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_dimension"},{"title":"Directed percolation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_percolation"},{"title":"Rushbrooke inequality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rushbrooke_inequality"},{"title":"Widom scaling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Widom_scaling"}]

Here's what I found about critical exponents:

## Physics Definition

Critical exponents describe the behavior of physical quantities near continuous phase transitions.(no content)It is believed, though not proven, that they are universal, i.e. they do not depend on the details of the physical system, but only on some of its general features.(no content)The defining property of criticality is that the characteristic length scale of the structure of the physical system, also known as the correlation length ξ, becomes infinite.(no content)As we approach the critical point, these diverging observables behave as power laws with exponents called critical exponents and are robust observables.

## Universality

Continuous phase transitions are classified by their universality class, each of which is characterized by a set of critical exponents.(no content)Critical exponents take the same values for very different physical systems—an intriguing phenomenon called universality, which is explained by the renormalization group.

## Mathematical Definition (Computer Science)

There's also a different usage in mathematics and computer science: The critical exponent of a finite or infinite sequence of symbols over a finite alphabet describes the largest number of times a contiguous subsequence can be repeated.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here's what I found about critical exponents:

## Physics Definition

Critical exponents describe the behavior of physical quantities near continuous phase transitions.(no content)It is believed, though not proven, that they are universal, i.e. they do not depend on the details of the physical system, but only on some of its general features.(no content)The defining property of criticality is that the characteristic length scale of the structure of the physical system, also known as the correlation length ξ, becomes infinite.(no content)As we approach the critical point, these diverging observables behave as power laws with exponents called critical exponents and are robust observables.

## Universality

Continuous phase transitions are classified by their universality class, each of which is characterized by a set of critical exponents.(no content)Critical exponents take the same values for very different physical systems—an intriguing phenomenon called universality, which is explained by the renormalization group.

## Mathematical Definition (Computer Science)

There's also a different usage in mathematics and computer science: The critical exponent of a finite or infinite sequence of symbols over a finite alphabet describes the largest number of times a contiguous subsequence can be repeated.

Web search results for query: "XY model"

Links: [{"title":"Classical XY model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model"},{"title":"Kosterlitz–Thouless transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosterlitz–Thouless_transition"},{"title":"Nicolet 1080 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicolet_1080"},{"title":"Ford Falcon (XY) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_Falcon_(XY)"},{"title":"Cutter location - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutter_location"},{"title":"Universality class - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"}]

Here are the key results from the web search on the XY model:

## Overview

The classical XY model (sometimes also called classical rotor (rotator) model or O(2) model) is a lattice model of statistical mechanics.(no content)The XY model is a two-dimensional vector spin model that possesses U(1) or circular symmetry.

## Phase Transitions

The behavior of the XY model depends on dimensionality:

- **One dimension**: In one dimension the XY model does not have a phase transition

- **Two dimensions**: In two dimensions it has the Berezinski-Kosterlitz-Thouless transition between the phases with exponentially and powerlaw decaying correlation functions.(no content)It is a transition from bound vortex-antivortex pairs at low temperatures to unpaired vortices and anti-vortices at some critical temperature.

- **Three and higher dimensions**: In three and higher dimensions the XY model has a ferromagnet-paramagnet phase transition.(no content)Many three-dimensional physical systems belong to the same universality class as the three dimensional XY model and share the same critical exponents, most notably easy-plane magnets and liquid Helium-4.

## Physical Relevance

BKT transitions can be found in several 2-D systems in condensed matter physics that are approximated by the XY model, including Josephson junction arrays and thin disordered superconducting granular films.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Phase transition"

Links: [{"title":"Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition"},{"title":"Cosmological phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmological_phase_transition"},{"title":"Superradiant phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superradiant_phase_transition"},{"title":"Rapid phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapid_phase_transition"},{"title":"Quantum phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_phase_transition"},{"title":"Sublimation (phase transition) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sublimation_(phase_transition)"},{"title":"Deposition (phase transition) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deposition_(phase_transition)"},{"title":"Phase change - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_change"},{"title":"Phase Transitions and Critical Phenomena - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_Transitions_and_Critical_Phenomena"},{"title":"Talk:Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Phase_transition"}]

## Phase Transition

A phase transition (or phase change) is the physical process of transition between one state of a medium and another.(no content)Commonly the term is used to refer to changes among the basic states of matter: solid, liquid, and gas, and in rare cases, plasma.

### How Phase Transitions Occur

A phase transition usually occurs when the pressure or temperature changes and the system crosses from one region to another, like water turning from liquid to solid as soon as the temperature drops below the freezing point.(no content)During a phase transition of a given medium, certain properties of the medium change as a result of the change of external conditions, such as temperature or pressure.

### Types of Changes

A liquid may become gas upon heating to its boiling point, resulting in an abrupt change in volume. Additionally, phase transitions can occur when a solid changes to a different structure without changing its chemical makeup. In elements, this is known as allotropy, whereas in compounds it is known as polymorphism. The change from one crystal structure to another, from a crystalline solid to an amorphous solid, or from one amorphous structure to another (polyamorphs) are all examples of solid to solid phase transitions.

### Other Examples

Phase transitions can also describe the change between different kinds of magnetic ordering. The most well-known is the transition between the ferromagnetic and paramagnetic phases of magnetic materials, which occurs at what is called the Curie point.(no content)Sublimation is the transition of a substance directly from the solid to the gas state, without passing through the liquid state.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Active matter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_matter"},{"title":"Active fluid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_fluid"},{"title":"Soft matter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soft_matter"},{"title":"M. Cristina Marchetti - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M._Cristina_Marchetti"},{"title":"Vicsek model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vicsek_model"},{"title":"John Toner (physicist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Toner_(physicist)"},{"title":"Hans Elsässer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hans_Els%C3%A4sser"},{"title":"Category:Soft matter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Soft_matter"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Peer review/Bash.org/archive1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Peer_review/Bash.org/archive1"},{"title":"Template talk:Episode list - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Episode_list"}]

## Active Matter

Based on the search results, here's an overview of active matter:

### Definition

Active matter is matter composed of large numbers of active "agents", each of which consumes energy in order to move or to exert mechanical forces.(no content)Such systems are intrinsically out of thermal equilibrium.

### Key Characteristics

Active matter systems break time reversal symmetry because energy is being continually dissipated by the individual constituents.

### Biological and Synthetic Examples

Most examples of active matter are biological in origin and span all the scales of the living, from bacteria and self-organising bio-polymers such as microtubules and actin to schools of fish and flocks of birds. Additionally, a great deal of current experimental work is devoted to synthetic systems such as artificial self-propelled particles.

### The Vicsek Model

Active matter is a relatively new material classification in soft matter: the most extensively studied model, the Vicsek model, dates from 1995.(no content)The Vicsek model consists in point-like self-propelled particles that evolve at constant speed and align their velocity with their neighbours' one in presence of noise. Such a model shows collective motion at high density of particles or low noise on the alignment.

### Research Approaches

Research in active matter combines analytical techniques, numerical simulations and experiments. Notable analytical approaches include hydrodynamics, kinetic theory, and non-equilibrium statistical physics.

## Active Matter

Based on the search results, here's an overview of active matter:

### Definition

Active matter is matter composed of large numbers of active "agents", each of which consumes energy in order to move or to exert mechanical forces.(no content)Such systems are intrinsically out of thermal equilibrium.

### Key Characteristics

Active matter systems break time reversal symmetry because energy is being continually dissipated by the individual constituents.

### Biological and Synthetic Examples

Most examples of active matter are biological in origin and span all the scales of the living, from bacteria and self-organising bio-polymers such as microtubules and actin to schools of fish and flocks of birds. Additionally, a great deal of current experimental work is devoted to synthetic systems such as artificial self-propelled particles.

### The Vicsek Model

Active matter is a relatively new material classification in soft matter: the most extensively studied model, the Vicsek model, dates from 1995.(no content)The Vicsek model consists in point-like self-propelled particles that evolve at constant speed and align their velocity with their neighbours' one in presence of noise. Such a model shows collective motion at high density of particles or low noise on the alignment.

### Research Approaches

Research in active matter combines analytical techniques, numerical simulations and experiments. Notable analytical approaches include hydrodynamics, kinetic theory, and non-equilibrium statistical physics.

Web search results for query: "Mean field theory"

Links: [{"title":"Mean-field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_theory"},{"title":"Dynamical mean-field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamical_mean-field_theory"},{"title":"Mean-field game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mean-field_game_theory"},{"title":"Polymer field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polymer_field_theory"},{"title":"Field (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_(physics)"},{"title":"Field-theoretic simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-theoretic_simulation"},{"title":"Ring (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Identity type - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Identity_type"},{"title":"Algebraic quantum field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_quantum_field_theory"},{"title":"Effective theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effective_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Mean Field Theory:

## Definition

In physics and probability theory, Mean-field theory (MFT) or Self-consistent field theory studies the behavior of high-dimensional random (stochastic) models by studying a simpler model that approximates the original by averaging over degrees of freedom.

## Core Concept

The main idea of MFT is to replace all interactions to any one body with an average or effective interaction, sometimes called a molecular field. This reduces any many-body problem into an effective one-body problem.

## Advantages and Applications

The ease of solving MFT problems means that some insight into the behavior of the system can be obtained at a lower computational cost.(no content)MFT has since been applied to a wide range of fields outside of physics, including statistical inference, graphical models, neuroscience, artificial intelligence, epidemic models, queueing theory, computer-network performance.

## Mathematical Framework

In field theory, the Hamiltonian may be expanded in terms of the magnitude of fluctuations around the mean of the field. In this context, MFT can be viewed as the "zeroth-order" expansion of the Hamiltonian in fluctuations.

## Limitations

In general, dimensionality plays an active role in determining whether a mean-field approach will work for any particular problem. There is sometimes a critical dimension above which MFT is valid and below which it is not.

Web search results for query: "Ising model"

Links: [{"title":"Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model"},{"title":"Square lattice Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Square_lattice_Ising_model"},{"title":"Transverse-field Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse-field_Ising_model"},{"title":"High-dimensional Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-dimensional_Ising_model"},{"title":"Two-dimensional critical Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-dimensional_critical_Ising_model"},{"title":"Ising critical exponents","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_critical_exponents"},{"title":"Ernst Ising - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_Ising"},{"title":"Construction of an irreducible Markov chain in the Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construction_of_an_irreducible_Markov_chain_in_the_Ising_model"},{"title":"Spherical model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spherical_model"},{"title":"Swendsen–Wang algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swendsen%E2%80%93Wang_algorithm"}]

## Ising Model Overview

The Ising model (or Lenz–Ising model), named after the physicists Ernst Ising and Wilhelm Lenz, is a mathematical model of ferromagnetism in statistical mechanics. 

### Basic Structure

The model consists of discrete variables that represent magnetic dipole moments of atomic "spins" that can be in one of two states (+1 or −1). The spins are arranged in a graph, usually a lattice (where the local structure repeats periodically in all directions), allowing each spin to interact with its neighbors.

### Physical Behavior

Neighboring spins that agree have a lower energy than those that disagree; the system tends to the lowest energy but heat disturbs this tendency, thus creating the possibility of different structural phases.(no content)In a ferromagnetic Ising model, spins desire to be aligned: the configurations in which adjacent spins are of the same sign have higher probability.

### Historical Development

The Ising model was invented by the physicist Wilhelm Lenz (1920), who gave it as a problem to his student Ernst Ising.(no content)The one-dimensional Ising model was solved by Ising (1925) alone in his 1924 thesis; it has no phase transition. The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is much harder and was only given an analytic description much later, by Lars Onsager (1944).

### Significance

The two-dimensional square-lattice Ising model is one of the simplest statistical models to show a phase transition.(no content)Today, each year, about 800 papers are published that use the model to address problems in such diverse fields as neural networks, protein folding, biological membranes and social behavior.

Links: [{"title":"Symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Chiral symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chiral_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"1964 PRL symmetry breaking papers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1964_PRL_symmetry_breaking_papers"},{"title":"Explicit symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicit_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Symmetry-breaking constraints - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry-breaking_constraints"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking and cortical rotation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_Breaking_and_Cortical_Rotation"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking of escaping ants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking_of_escaping_ants"},{"title":"Electroweak scale - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electroweak_scale"},{"title":"Higgs mechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Higgs_mechanism"}]

Here's comprehensive information about symmetry breaking:

## General Definition

In physics, symmetry breaking is a phenomenon where a disordered but symmetric state collapses into an ordered, but less symmetric state.(no content)This phenomenon is fundamental to quantum field theory (QFT), and further, contemporary understandings of physics.

## Types of Symmetry Breaking

Symmetry breaking can be distinguished into two types, explicit and spontaneous, characterized by whether the equations of motion fail to be invariant, or the ground state fails to be invariant.

**Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking:** Spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs when this relation breaks down, while the underlying physical laws remain symmetrical.(no content)This is the idea that for a physical system, the lowest energy configuration (the vacuum state) is not the most symmetric configuration of the system.

**Explicit Symmetry Breaking:** In theoretical physics, explicit symmetry breaking is the breaking of a symmetry of a theory by terms in its defining equations of motion (most typically, to the Lagrangian or the Hamiltonian) that do not respect the symmetry.

## Applications and Examples

Phases of matter, such as crystals, magnets, and conventional superconductors, as well as simple phase transitions can be described by spontaneous symmetry breaking.(no content)It plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.(no content)Gauge bosons can acquire non-zero masses as a result of spontaneous symmetry breaking within gauge invariant models of the universe.

In biology, symmetry breaking in biology is the process by which uniformity is broken, or the number of points to view invariance are reduced, to generate a more structured and improbable state.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Symmetry breaking can be distinguished into two types, explicit and spontaneous, characterized by whether the equations of motion fail to be invariant, or the ground state fails to be invariant.

**Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking:** Spontaneous symmetry breaking occurs when this relation breaks down, while the underlying physical laws remain symmetrical.(no content)This is the idea that for a physical system, the lowest energy configuration (the vacuum state) is not the most symmetric configuration of the system.

**Explicit Symmetry Breaking:** In theoretical physics, explicit symmetry breaking is the breaking of a symmetry of a theory by terms in its defining equations of motion (most typically, to the Lagrangian or the Hamiltonian) that do not respect the symmetry.

## Applications and Examples

Phases of matter, such as crystals, magnets, and conventional superconductors, as well as simple phase transitions can be described by spontaneous symmetry breaking.(no content)It plays a central role in the Glashow–Weinberg–Salam model which forms part of the Standard Model modelling the electroweak sector.(no content)Gauge bosons can acquire non-zero masses as a result of spontaneous symmetry breaking within gauge invariant models of the universe.

In biology, symmetry breaking in biology is the process by which uniformity is broken, or the number of points to view invariance are reduced, to generate a more structured and improbable state.

Based on the web search results, here are the main meanings of "nonreciprocal interactions":

## Genetics - Chromosomal Translocations

Nonreciprocal translocation is a chromosomal abnormality that involves the one-way transfer of genes from one chromosome to another non-homologous chromosome.(no content)This transfer will always be unbalanced resulting in genetic imbalance.(no content)In nonreciprocal translocations, the acceptor chromosome gains material but the donor chromosome does not accept material in exchange, causing loss of genetic material which may have varying degrees of impact.

## Physics - Electromagnetic Devices

Nonreciprocal gyromagnetic devices such as resonant isolators and differential phase shifters depend on a microwave signal presenting a rotating (circularly polarized) magnetic field to a statically magnetized ferrite body.

The search results reveal that "nonreciprocal interactions" has different meanings depending on the field of study, with the most prominent being the genetic context where material transfer occurs in only one direction between chromosomes.

Links: [{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Cosmological phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmological_phase_transition"},{"title":"Landau theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landau_theory"},{"title":"Talk:Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Phase_transition"},{"title":"Electroweak epoch - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electroweak_epoch"},{"title":"Berezinskii–Kosterlitz–Thouless transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosterlitz-Thouless_transition"},{"title":"Ferroics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferroics"},{"title":"Topological order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_phase"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of phase transitions and symmetry breaking:

## What is Symmetry Breaking?

Spontaneous symmetry breaking is a spontaneous process of symmetry breaking, by which a physical system in a symmetric state spontaneously ends up in an asymmetric state.(no content)In particular, it can describe systems where the equations of motion or the Lagrangian obey symmetries, but the lowest-energy vacuum solutions do not exhibit that same symmetry.

## Connection to Phase Transitions

Phase transitions often involve a symmetry breaking process. For instance, the cooling of a fluid into a crystalline solid breaks continuous translation symmetry: each point in the fluid has the same properties, but each point in a crystal does not have the same properties.(no content)Typically, the high-temperature phase contains more symmetries than the low-temperature phase due to spontaneous symmetry breaking.

## Order Parameter

Spontaneously symmetry-broken phases of matter are characterized by an order parameter that describes the quantity which breaks the symmetry under consideration. For example, in a magnet, the order parameter is the local magnetization.

## Examples

Common examples include:
- The ferromagnet is the canonical system that spontaneously breaks the continuous symmetry of the spins below the Curie temperature
- The phase transition between a liquid and a crystal is a transition that reduces the continuous translation symmetry of the liquid to the discrete symmetry of the crystal.
- As the universe expanded and cooled, the vacuum underwent a series of symmetry-breaking phase transitions. For example, the electroweak transition broke the SU(2)×U(1) symmetry of the electroweak field into the U(1) symmetry of the present-day electromagnetic field.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Spontaneous symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spontaneous_symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_transition"},{"title":"Symmetry breaking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_breaking"},{"title":"Cosmological phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmological_phase_transition"},{"title":"Landau theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landau_theory"},{"title":"Talk:Phase transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Phase_transition"},{"title":"Electroweak epoch - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electroweak_epoch"},{"title":"Berezinskii–Kosterlitz–Thouless transition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kosterlitz-Thouless_transition"},{"title":"Ferroics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferroics"},{"title":"Topological order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_phase"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of phase transitions and symmetry breaking:

## What is Symmetry Breaking?

Spontaneous symmetry breaking is a spontaneous process of symmetry breaking, by which a physical system in a symmetric state spontaneously ends up in an asymmetric state.(no content)In particular, it can describe systems where the equations of motion or the Lagrangian obey symmetries, but the lowest-energy vacuum solutions do not exhibit that same symmetry.

## Connection to Phase Transitions

Phase transitions often involve a symmetry breaking process. For instance, the cooling of a fluid into a crystalline solid breaks continuous translation symmetry: each point in the fluid has the same properties, but each point in a crystal does not have the same properties.(no content)Typically, the high-temperature phase contains more symmetries than the low-temperature phase due to spontaneous symmetry breaking.

## Order Parameter

Spontaneously symmetry-broken phases of matter are characterized by an order parameter that describes the quantity which breaks the symmetry under consideration. For example, in a magnet, the order parameter is the local magnetization.

## Examples

Common examples include:
- The ferromagnet is the canonical system that spontaneously breaks the continuous symmetry of the spins below the Curie temperature
- The phase transition between a liquid and a crystal is a transition that reduces the continuous translation symmetry of the liquid to the discrete symmetry of the crystal.
- As the universe expanded and cooled, the vacuum underwent a series of symmetry-breaking phase transitions. For example, the electroweak transition broke the SU(2)×U(1) symmetry of the electroweak field into the U(1) symmetry of the present-day electromagnetic field.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.
